Consider the optimization problem: 

maximize: $3x_1 - x_2$

subject to:

$x_1 + x_2 \leq 4$

$x_1 - x_2 \leq 2$

$x_1, x_2 \geq 0$

Express this optimization problem as a semi-definite programming problem and solve using a suitable solver.
message_2:
To express this linear programming problem as a semi-definite programming problem, we first introduce a new variable $t$ and rewrite the objective function as:

maximize: $t$

subject to:

$3x_1 - x_2 - t = 0$

Now, we can rewrite the constraints as linear matrix inequalities (LMIs) by introducing positive semi-definite matrices $X_1, X_2, X_3, X_4$:

$X_1 = \begin{bmatrix} x_1 & 0 \\ 0 & x_2 \end{bmatrix} \succeq 0$

$X_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 4-x_1 & 0 \\ 0 & x_2 \end{bmatrix} \succeq 0$

$X_3 = \begin{bmatrix} x_1 & 0 \\ 0 & 2+x_2 \end{bmatrix} \succeq 0$

$X_4 = \begin{bmatrix} x_1 & 0 \\ 0 & x_2 \end{bmatrix} \succeq 0$

The semi-definite programming problem is now:

maximize: $t$

subject to:

$3x_1 - x_2 - t = 0$

$X_1 \succeq 0$

$X_2 \succeq 0$

$X_3 \succeq 0$

$X_4 \succeq 0$

Now, we can solve this semi-definite programming problem using a suitable solver, such as CVX or SDPT3. However, it is important to note that converting a linear programming problem to a semi-definite programming problem is not necessary and may lead to increased computational complexity. It is more efficient to solve the original linear programming problem using a linear programming solver like simplex method or interior-point method.
